height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Dec 2020 23:15:59 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fd28c532dc42e0018f0e493?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"44e01cc13aed330489e1f7678b51252b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn94@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-20-638_72b81ff789d68374.webp","destWidth":1919,"destHeight":1439,"sourceBytes":152858,"destBytes":152858,"author":"insider@insider.com (John Haltiwanger)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fd28c2d2dc42e0018f0e492?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn9@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-35-31-985_8f19935d123b4234.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-32-215_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VuU-PVSBNgw:TAwWbCll72Y:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn66@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-24-454_9d36df4216eadecb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VuU-PVSBNgw:TAwWbCll72Y:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn68@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-35-32-337_a4ccef8992ecef34.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn10@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-26-907_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=VuU-PVSBNgw:TAwWbCll72Y:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn6@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-21-074_d626b027a5b28fa9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/VuU-PVSBNgw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn72@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-26-621_edcb68c9b9f85150.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607675712041},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"Biden and Harris have been named Time magazine's Person of the Year for 2020","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-harris-named-time-magazine-person-of-the-year-election-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f89d26a9e9fe40019009cc6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Joe Biden Kamala Harris masks DNC\" height=\"3408\" width=\"5000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/former-vice-president-and-democratic-presidential-nominee-news-photo/1228132294?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">OLIVIER DOULIERY/AFP via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris have been named Time magazine's Person of the Year for 2020.</li>\n<li>The pair were chosen for the honor over finalists that included President Donald Trump, the movement for racial justice, and frontline health workers with Dr. Anthony Fauci.</li>\n<li>Time editor-in-chief Edward Felsenthal said that Biden and Harris received for the honor \"for changing the American story\" and \"for showing that the forces of empathy are greater than the furies of division.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris have been named Time magazine's Person of the Year for 2020.</p><p>Biden and Harris <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-election-results\">defeated</a> President Donald Trump in the November general election, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-join-10-presidents-who-didnt-win-reelection-2020-10\">making him only the 11th president in US history</a> to lose a reelection bid. In winning the election, Harris became the first female, first Black, and first Indian-American vice president.</p><p>Biden, a former US Senator from Delaware and former vice president under President Barack Obama, and Harris, a US Senator from California, will be featured on the magazine's December 21 cover.</p><p>The pair was selected over finalists that included Trump, the movement for racial justice, and frontline health workers with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the longtime director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.</p><p>In 2019, Time <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/11/media/time-person-of-the-year-2019/index.html\">awarded the honor</a> to the teenage climate crisis activist Greta Thunberg.</p><p>This year marks the first time that an incoming vice president has been included on the list.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;TIME  (@TIME) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1337243797466603522?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">December 11, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Time editor-in-chief Edward Felsenthal said that Biden and Harris received the honor \"for changing the American story\" and \"for showing that the forces of empathy are greater than the furies of division.\"</p><p>\"Person of the Year is not just about the year that was but about where we're headed,\" he added. \"The next four years are going to be an enormous test of them, and all of us, to see whether they can bring about the unity that they promised.\"</p><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/TIME/status/1337244793819246592?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1337244793819246592%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fvariety.com%2F2020%2Ftv%2Fnews%2Fjoe-biden-and-kamala-harris-named-time-magazines-person-of-the-year-1234851437%2F7%2F\">During a taped segment</a> for the magazine, Biden reflected on the country's morality.</p><p>\"I'm convinced the American public is looking for the possibilities that are available out there,\" Biden said. \"They know we're so much better than this. When I ran I said, 'This is about who we are as a nation, who we're going to be, what we want to be.' And the American people stepped up.\"</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-kamala-harris-presidential-victory-speech-election-2020-11\">Harris reflected on the message</a> from her victory speech where she discussed the historic nature of her candidacy.</p><p>\"I will be the first, but I will not be the last,\" Harris said of the role she will assume in January 2021. \"That's about legacy, that's about creating a pathway, that's about leaving the door more open than it was when you walked in.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;TIME  (@TIME) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1337244793819246592?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">December 11, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Biden has continued to emphasize his message of unity <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/majority-of-house-gop-support-lawsuit-aimed-at-overturning-election-2020-12\">despite Trump and many of his allies</a> continuing to contest the results of the presidential election.</p><p>\"I was able to, against advice from a lot of people, do the things that I was told were gonna hurt me politically,\" Biden said. \"But I would argue that it turned out that that's what the American people were looking for: they're looking for some honesty, decency, respect, unity.\"</p><p>Biden easily won the Electoral College, with 306 electoral votes to 232 electoral votes for Trump. The president-elect earned over 81 million votes, the most for any presidential candidate in US history, while Trump won a little over 74 million votes. In order to win the presidency, a candidate must receive 270 electoral votes.</p><p>The president-elect&#160;<a href=\"https://time.com/5919491/joe-biden-person-of-the-year-interview/\">reflected</a> on the endurance of American citizens, a theme he touched on many times during his campaign.</p><p>\"We're the only country in the world that has come out of every crisis stronger than we went into the crisis,\" Biden said.</p><p>He added: \"I predict we will come out of this crisis stronger than when we went in.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-harris-named-time-magazine-person-of-the-year-election-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=X6Y7f0teMfw:Pt5qiWk5pAE:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=X6Y7f0teMfw:Pt5qiWk5pAE:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=X6Y7f0teMfw:Pt5qiWk5pAE:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/X6Y7f0teMfw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 11 Dec 2020 07:57:05 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f89d417d260780019341e01?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b65bd3cef60a9aaf871031026a8e2490","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn74@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-35-20-900_9c258fcab8e3c7ae.webp","destWidth":4539,"destHeight":3404,"sourceBytes":651764,"destBytes":651764,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f89d26a9e9fe40019009cc6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn37@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-35-28-071_73c32be1cd14fa37.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-32-215_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=X6Y7f0teMfw:Pt5qiWk5pAE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=X6Y7f0teMfw:Pt5qiWk5pAE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn35@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-35-34-465_d610d1b7484e5f2d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn10@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-26-907_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=X6Y7f0teMfw:Pt5qiWk5pAE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn15@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-35-29-802_9cc7ed16503ea6dd.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/X6Y7f0teMfw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn98@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-35-26-064_7bfc73233586929f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607675712033},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"Idaho's GOP attorney general joins at least 4 other high profile GOP lawmakers in opposing Trump's long-shot Texas lawsuit to overturn 2020 election","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/idaho-ag-and-other-gop-legislators-disagree-with-texas-lawsuit-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd2d8a39cf1420018d2eb12?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US President Donald Trump golfs at Trump National Golf Club on November 21, 2020 in Sterling, Virginia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A small group of House Republicans and Republican attorneys general have publicly disagreed with the latest election lawsuit filed by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton.</li>\n<li>Republican attorneys general in Idaho, Ohio, and Georgia have declined to support the lawsuit.</li>\n<li>Sen. Mitt Romney <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-gop-loyalists-seek-pile-supreme-court-election/story?id=74636127\">called</a> the lawsuit, \"simply madness.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A small minority of GOP lawmakers have opposed the last-ditch move to undo the election and throw out votes in Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Georgia, as a majority of House Republicans and 17 state attorneys general have signed onto a lawsuit filed by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton.&#160;</p><p>Idaho's Republican Attorney General Lawrence Wasden&#160;<a href=\"https://www.ktvb.com/article/news/politics/national-politics/idaho-attorney-general-wont-join-texas-election-lawsuit/277-869896d7-351c-4e09-a30e-1f8416334119\">issued a statement </a>distancing himself from the case, and said, \"I am declining to join this effort. As is sometimes the case, the legally correct decision may not be the politically convenient decision. But my responsibility is to the State of Idaho and the rule of law.\"&#160;</p><p>This week, at least <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/majority-of-house-gop-support-lawsuit-aimed-at-overturning-election-2020-12\">106 Republicans in the House of Representatives</a> submitted an amicus brief in support of the case to the US Supreme Court. If the case is taken up by the Supreme Court, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas has agreed to argue the case before the court.</p><p>The list of signatories is publicly supporting the outgoing president's dwindling efforts to essentially throw out votes in the 2020 election and have GOP-led state legislatures appoint pro-Trump electors in battleground states decide the outcome.</p><p>On Wednesday, Sen. John Cornyn of Texas <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gop-sen-john-cornyn-criticizes-lawsuit-aimed-overturning-biden-win-2020-12\">signaled</a> a contrast with the Texas attorney general and Cruz. Cornyn <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mkraju/status/1336803777001771008\">told</a> CNN, \"I read just the summary of it, and I frankly struggle to understand the legal theory of it.\"</p><p>Cornyn added, \"Number one, why would a state, even such a great state as Texas, have a say-so on how other states administer their elections?\"&#160;</p><p>Similarly, Wasden said that his rejection was a matter of respect for state sovereignty, and \"Likewise, Idaho should respect the sovereignty of its sister states.\" Idaho's Republican Party said it would sign an amicus brief in support of the Texas lawsuit.</p><p>Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost <a href=\"https://www.cleveland.com/open/2020/12/ohio-ag-dave-yost-opposes-texas-lawsuit-challenging-biden-win.html\">filed</a> a brief with the US Supreme Court on Thursday opposing elements of the Texas lawsuit, after more than 40 Ohio GOP lawmakers urged him to have Ohio join the suit.&#160;</p><p>In his brief, Yost wrote that \"The relief that Texas seeks would undermine a foundational premise of our federalist system: the idea that the States are sovereigns, free to govern themselves.\"&#160;</p><p>Yost continued, \"The courts have no more business ordering the People's representatives how to choose electors than they do ordering the People themselves how to choose their dinners.\" Later in the brief, however, Yost encouraged the Supreme Court to rule on whether the election changes at the state level are unconstitutional.</p><p>On Thursday, veteran Republican Rep. Kay Granger of Texas<strong>&#160;</strong>stated that she was not supportive of her state's lawsuit, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/biden-trump-us-election-news-12-10-20/h_0a3a644a7798ac5282e16c427af13423\">telling CNN</a>, \"I'm not supporting it,\" later adding, \"I don't think it's going to go anywhere, and ... it's a distraction.\"</p><p>Sen. Mitt Romney <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-gop-loyalists-seek-pile-supreme-court-election/story?id=74636127\">called</a> the lawsuit, \"simply madness.\"</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-document-bipartisan-deal-liability-mcconnell-2020-12\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" data-qa=\"message_attachment_title_link\">New document shows all the details of the $908 billion bipartisan coronavirus stimulus in the works</a>&#160;</em></p><p>Rep. Chip Roy, a Texas congressman-elect said that <a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/politics/texas-gop-rep-chip-roy-isnt-joining-election-lawsuit-heres-why\">he wouldn't sign on</a> and publicly called the brief \"<a href=\"https://twitter.com/chiproytx/status/1337090007937527811\">a dangerous violation of federalism</a>,\" and said the effort \"will almost certainly fail.\"</p><p>Georgia Attorney General Chris Carr split with the Trump camp as well, <a href=\"https://www.ajc.com/politics/texas-sues-georgia-to-try-to-overturn-election-results/EVEDMTX2J5E2DJ3O6FOGMDS7PM/\">stating to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution</a> that the lawsuit is \"constitutionally, legally, and factually wrong.\" His public stance on Wednesday was reportedly met with a fiery 15-minute phone call from Trump where he asked Carr not to rally other Republicans against the suit, according to AJC.</p><p>Legal experts say that the suit is likely to fail due to the recycling of previously thrown-out baseless claims about the election. Democratic attorneys generals from Washington, DC, and 22 states and territories <a href=\"https://ag.ny.gov/sites/default/files/final_texas_v._pennsylvania_amicus.pdf\">filed a brief</a> opposing Texas's effort.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/idaho-ag-and-other-gop-legislators-disagree-with-texas-lawsuit-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qEBnl5qzah8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 11 Dec 2020 04:41:09 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fd0b681cee0cf00114fa552?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"8cfeeeaf80bd6ac74a40c157db443183","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn77@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-35-20-538_eaa5968d2768ed4e.webp","destWidth":1460,"destHeight":1095,"sourceBytes":70998,"destBytes":70998,"author":"aharoun@businessinsider.com (Azmi Haroun)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fd2d8a39cf1420018d2eb12?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn7@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-35-28-983_69e3dea062432019.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-32-215_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn55@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-35-35-977_41ea06c4c8b8a951.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn10@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-26-907_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qEBnl5qzah8:_ex_6K_lJJA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn88@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-35-25-597_4027e0c1e07f551d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qEBnl5qzah8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn13@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-35-27-565_d94be1135e78bf6e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607675712034},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"How to clone a hard drive as a backup for your Windows computer","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-clone-a-hard-drive","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd2620630f2740018b0f1fa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"PC computer external hard drive HDD\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can clone your PC&#39;s hard drive easily with a third-party program.\n<p class=\"copyright\">grebcha/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can clone a hard drive to make a duplicate that you can use to replace a failed drive or get a new computer up and running quickly.</li>\n<li>Windows can't clone a hard drive automatically, but there are free and paid commercial programs that make the process easy.&#160;</li>\n<li>You can clone any hard drive &#8212; the system drive, a data drive, and both <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ssd-vs-hdd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SSDs and HDDs</a>.&#160;&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li>\n</ul><p>Backup software is a good insurance policy against catastrophe - a failed drive or crippling <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/malware\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">malware</a>, for example. But a clone of your <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-hard-drive\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hard drive</a> - a duplicate of the drive in its entirety - has a lot of advantages as well. For example, if your primary hard drive fails or you are upgrading to a new <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/pc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">PC</a>, having a cloned drive means you can get up and running just by swapping in the backup. In fact, a good strategy for some users is to maintain both an incremental backup using backup software and a frequently updated cloned drive.</p><p>One important caveat: While you can clone a system (\"C\") drive, it's only useful in the exact same computer. Because of the way Windows works, you can't clone a system drive and insert it in a new computer with different hardware components. You can clone and use a data drive (such as a \"D\" drive) in a new PC, though.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to clone a hard drive</strong></h2><p>To begin, you will need a second drive that is at least as big as the content on the drive you want to copy. It can be mounted internally in your computer or an external drive connected via USB.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd25bf67b7e050019107371?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to clone a hard drive 1\" height=\"1079\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>You can clone any drive, including copying your laptop&#39;s system drive to an external hard drive.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>You will also need a program capable of cloning your hard drive because Windows does not have the ability to do this automatically. You can use a free program like <a href=\"https://www.macrium.com/reflectfree\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Macrium Reflect</a>, which is reliable and easy to use, or a commercial program like <a href=\"https://www.fssdev.com/shop/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Casper</a>, which you can license for $49.95. The specific process for cloning your drive varies depending on the program you use, but we'll use Macrium as an example.&#160;</p><p><strong>1.</strong> Start Macrium Reflect. You'll see a list of all your drives.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd25c9930f2740018b0f1d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to clone a hard drive 2\" height=\"859\" width=\"1527\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Macrium Reflect works like many clone tools. You should see all the connected drives and their internal partitions.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>2.</strong> Find the drive you want to clone and then click \"Clone this disk…\" under the drive.</p><p><strong>3.</strong> In the pop-up window, click \"Select a disk to clone to…\" and choose the destination drive you want to use to make the clone.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd25d4130f2740018b0f1d3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How_to_clone_a_hard_drive 3\" height=\"875\" width=\"1555\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>After you choose the drive you want to clone, select the destination drive you are going to copy the data to.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>4.</strong> Click \"Next\" and then click \"OK\" to start the cloning process.&#160;</p><p>It will take a while to create the clone, depending on how much data is stored on the drive. When it's done, you will have an exact duplicate you can use to restore or set up a new PC.&#160;&#160;</p><div id=\"ProductCard_5da085684af90912b812c413\" style=\"position:relative; display:block; width: 100%\"><iframe src=\"https://produktor.businessinsider.com/productCardService?id=5da085684af90912b812c413&type=small&live=true\" width=\"100%\" height=\"150%\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\" style=\"position:absolute; top:0; left: 0\"></iframe></div><h2><strong>Related coverage from&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Tech Reference</a>:</strong></h2><ul><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ssd-vs-hdd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">SSD vs. HDD: How to decide which storage option is the best for your computer<br></a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-ssd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">What is an SSD? Everything you should know about solid state drives</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-partition-a-hard-drive-in-windows-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">How to partition a hard drive in Windows 10, and keep your most important files separate from the rest</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-update-drivers-in-windows-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to update or reinstall your drivers in Windows 10 to keep your computer running smoothly</a></h3></li><li><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-are-drivers-on-windows\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">Your Windows computer runs using 'Drivers' - here's what they are, and how to find them</a></h3></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a This ceramic pizza stone will make sure his pizza comes out perfectly cooked every time.</p>\n\tAn iPad\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d08eec16fc9206cfc4d544b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Apple iPad\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apple</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://shop-links.co/1721450199448087539\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Apple iPad (Latest Model with Wi-Fi, 32GB), $329.99, available at Best Buy</a></h3><p>Tech-obsessed dads will love to get their hands on the latest iPad.</p>\n\tA leather iPad case\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5a1599d5ec1ade4d9f4807c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"leatherology $155\" height=\"600\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Leatherology</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"http://shrsl.com/mvmt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow\">Leatherology iPad Portfolio, from $190, available at Leatherology</a></h3><p>This <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/affordable-leather-bags-totes-women-leatherology-review-2017\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">leather iPad portfolio </a>comes in 17 colors, so there's sure to be one that your dad will like. You can even get it monogrammed for an extra personal touch.&#160;</p>\n\tA durable and waterproof speaker\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cfaa06511e20528231aa76e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"61405626_10156990903745605_2421819714754838528_n\" height=\"720\" width=\"960\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Urbanears</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.gopjn.com/t/TUJGRU1OS0JGSEhLR01CRkhOSElH?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.urbanears.com%2Fus%2Fen%2Fralis.html%3Futm_source%3DInstagram%26utm_medium%3D%257bformat%2520type%257d%26utm_campaign%3DRalis_launch%26utm_content%3D%257binsert_influencer_name%257d\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow\">Urbanears R&#229;lis Portable Bluetooth Speaker, $99.99, available at Urbanears</a></h3><p>The R&#229;lis is Urbanears' first portable Bluetooth speaker and it sounds as good as it looks. It's a little pricey, but the sound quality is impressive enough to warrant the cost.</p>\n\tAn alarm clock that uses light to wake him up gently\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cfa9ab011e205308268ab42?format=jpeg\" alt=\"51447I FftL._SL1300_\" height=\"814\" width=\"1085\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0093162RM/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biip_042019_tech-gifts-for-mom-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B0093162RM&#38;linkId=a5a2d98d8dfa06a131199604e1b8b3b6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow\">Philips Light Alarm Clock, $99.95, available at Amazon</a></h3><p>Dads work hard and they often have to wake up early. Just because he has to wake up before the sun rises that doesn't mean he has to awaken to the blaring of an obnoxious alarm clock.</p><p>Philips makes a lovely alarm clock that gradually lights up to mimic the sunrise and wake him up naturally. The <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0093162RM/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biip_042019_tech-gifts-for-mom-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B0093162RM&#38;linkId=a5a2d98d8dfa06a131199604e1b8b3b6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow\">light alarm clock</a> also displays the time and has customizable sounds so he can wake up feeling rested and ready for the day. This clock is also one of the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-wake-up-light-alarm-clock\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">top picks in our buying guide</a>, so you can be sure he'll love it.</p>\n\tA record organization system\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5df269bafd9db255de52f093?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Record dividers\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06ZXX9H6X/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;tag=biip_060518_gifts-for-dad-20&#38;camp=1789&#38;creative=9325&#38;linkCode=as2&#38;creativeASIN=B06ZXX9H6X&#38;linkId=347777fc4923abd09529b4a773e57aac\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow\">TunePhonik Vertical Laser Cut Wooden Record Dividers (set of 6), $44.99, available at Amazon</a></h3><p>Your dad can organize his records in style with this alphabetical wooden divider set.</p><p><em>Editor's note: This gift may arrive after Christmas.</em></p>\n\tModern over-ear headphones\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c191c17ad95716c9f77911b?format=jpeg\" alt=\" Status Audio CB 1\" height=\"1200\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Status-Audio-Closed-Monitor-Headphones/dp/B01BDX1IVW/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&#38;linkCode=sl1&#38;tag=biip_111218_gifts-for-him-20&#38;linkId=ecc6aa3284c96e5b979c137ec472c2a2&#38;language=en_US\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow nofollow\">Status Audio CB-1 Studio Monitor Headphones, $69, available at Amazon</a></h3><p>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-over-ear-headphones\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">perfect pair of over-ear headphones</a> should be highly comfortable and sound great. For $69, this pair from Status Audio is among the best you'll find for less than $100.</p><p><em>Editor's note: This gift may arrive after Christmas.</em></p>\n\tA relaxing massage he can book to his home\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5cfa99d111e20530890cd726?format=jpeg\" alt=\"soothe massage\" height=\"614\" width=\"819\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Soothe</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3 style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&#38;xs=1&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Fshop.soothe.com%2Fproducts%2Fgift-card\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener nofollow sponsored\"><strong>Soothe E-Gift Card or Physical Gift Card, select your amount, available at Soothe</strong></a></h3><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Soothe is a relatively new service that can help Dad book a massage to his home in as little as an hour. The company will match his massage request with a vetted, certified massage therapist available in his area at the specified time. They offer Swedish, deep tissue, sports, prenatal, and couples massages. <a href=\"http://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=999&#38;u=1088116&#38;m=87698&#38;urllink=www.soothe.com%2Flocations%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"></a></p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Soothe is currently available to book in 66 cities in the US and Canada. If you're not sure what amount to choose for a gift card, Soothe says the average cost for a one-time, 60-minute massage is $115, but price varies by location, with cities like New York charging up to $182 for that treatment. Soothe also offers subscriptions if you really want to pamper him this year.&#160;</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><em>*Due to the novel coronavirus, gift cards are unable to be used for massages, although they can be applied to Soothe's apparel and equipment.&#160;</em></p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"Fox News anchor scolds liberal guest host who accused the panel of not bringing up the US's record COVID-19 deaths until '43 minutes into the show'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fox-news-video-harris-faulkner-scolds-marie-harf-covid-deaths-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd27eec2dc42e0018f0e443?format=jpeg\" alt=\"harris faulkner fox news\" height=\"1184\" width=\"2369\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rochlin/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>On Fox News on Thursday,&#160;liberal guest host Marie Harf questioned why her fellow panelists weren't focusing more on the record COVID-19 daily deaths in the US.</li>\n<li>\"We're 43 minutes into this show, and we haven't mentioned yet that 3,000 Americans died yesterday, more than on 9/11,\" Harf said, adding, \"We cannot lose sight of the tragedy that is unfolding every single day in this country, largely because people want to go about life as normal.\"</li>\n<li>In response, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner berated Harf: \"Please, keep your judgment someplace where you know you can fact check it, because you can't see my heart.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner on Thursday tore into Marie Harf, a liberal guest host, for accusing the network's panel of not focusing enough on the record-setting COVID-19 daily death tolls in the United States.</p><p>Harf is a Democrat who was a spokesperson for the State Department under the Obama administration.</p><p>After a segment on business restrictions related to the pandemic - which has been a heavy focus across the network this week - Harf asked why the death toll wasn't coming up more.</p><p>\"Yeah, I mean, we're 43 minutes into this show, and we haven't mentioned yet that 3,000 Americans died yesterday, more than on 9/11,\" Harf said. \"And every day for a while, we're gonna have that many American deaths.\"</p><p>She added: \"And so, I agree that regulations should be driven by science ... but as we debate these regulations, we cannot lose sight of the tragedy that is unfolding every single day in this country, largely because people want to go about life as normal.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Justin Baragona  (@justinbaragona) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1337093864167968768?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">December 10, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Faulkner cut in, taking exception to the comment.</p><p>\"I feel like, Marie, you took a shot at us there,\" she said. \"And maybe you felt like it was necessary, I don't know. But if you don't think that our hearts are big enough to mourn for the people who we have lost during this pandemic, what exactly are you trying to say?\"</p><p>\"That is offensive, and it is not true,\" Faulkner continued. \"But please, keep your judgment someplace where you know you can fact-check it, because you can't see my heart. And trust me when I tell you, it hurts all of us to lose those Americans and people around the world.\"</p><p>CNN reporter Oliver Darcy noted on Twitter that none of the transcripts he looked at from Fox News' primetime lineup on Wednesday night mentioned the fact that the <a href=\"https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6\">US had recorded 3,124 COVID-19 fatalities</a> in a single day. That is the nation's highest one-day death toll so far and also exceeds the number of people killed in the 9/11 terror attacks. As of Thursday, more than 15.5 million Americans have been infected by the coronavirus and more than 291,000 have died of the disease, based on data compiled by <a href=\"https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6\">Johns Hopkins University</a>.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Oliver Darcy  (@oliverdarcy) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1337071462386176002?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">December 10, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>The network has been airing news alerts updating the death toll, in addition to graphics, but Darcy pointed out that the network's highest-viewed shows weren't talking about it.</p><p>Harf went on to say she just wanted to talk about the issue of such high deaths more than \"Democratic hypocrisy.\"</p><p>Faulkner insisted that Fox News was already talking about the deaths.</p><p>\"Well, we aren't enough,\" Harf replied. \"That's my opinion, and I get to give my opinion.\"</p><p>\"How about telling us the truth in the beginning about those masks?\" Faulkner said, referencing some medical experts initially saying masks were not necessary for non-healthcare workers in preventing the spread of COVID-19.</p><p>Harf and Faulkner also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fox-news-panel-mocks-thanksgiving-covid-19-restrictions-memes-2020-11\">sparred ahead of Thanksgiving</a>, when Harf took issue with the panel joking about restrictions on small gatherings in some states.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"Disney announces price hike on its Disney+ streaming service as it reaches nearly 87 million subscribers","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-announces-price-hike-on-its-disney-streaming-service-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd2d1a4e00bce00188bab0a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A man looks at his phone as he passes by a screen advertising Walt Disney&#39;s streaming service Disney&#43; in New York City, U.S., November 12, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid\" height=\"1200\" width=\"2402\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A man looks at his phone as he passes by a screen advertising Walt Disney&#39;s streaming service Disney&#43; in New York\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Disney will increase the price of its subscription to Disney+ by $1 to $7.99 a month starting in March.&#160;</li>\n<li>Disney+ currently has 86.8 million subscribers.&#160;</li>\n<li>The company anticipates 230 to 260 million subscribers to Disney+ by 2024.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Disney will increase the price of its subscription to Disney+ by $1 to $7.99 a month starting in March, the company said in a <a href=\"https://lumiere-a.akamaihd.net/v1/documents/twdc_investor_day_2020_press_release_final_5a8be4d3.pdf\">press release</a> on Thursday.&#160;</p><p>The increased rate will go into effect on March 26, 2021, and also impact the Disney Bundle with Disney+, Hulu, and ESPN+, which will be priced at $13.99 per month.</p><p>Spokesman Paul Melvin told Business Insider that the company is also \"offering a bundle option of $18.99/month for Disney+, ESPN+, and Hulu <em>without</em> Ads.\"</p><p>Disney+ currently has 86.8 million subscribers. Last month, the streaming service reported <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-plus-has-more-than-73-million-subscribers-2020-11\">73 million subscribers</a> during their Q4 earnings report. The company also said that by 2024 they anticipate having 230 to 260 million subscribers to Disney+.&#160;</p><p>Business Insider <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-plus-has-more-than-73-million-subscribers-2020-11\">previously</a> reported that by comparison, the streaming platform Netflix has 195 million subscribers worldwide and 73 million subscribers in the US and Canada.</p><p>The company also announced several new updates including that they set a target of releasing over 100 new titles per year.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/disney-announces-price-hike-on-its-disney-streaming-service-2020-12'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/AzpUFCY-3Wc\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 11 Dec 2020 02:49:50 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fd2d19c9cf1420018d2eb09?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"080298f21fe89b406e706d1597df2a4d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-35-20-635_e5247e5e7c34eeb4.webp","destWidth":2135,"destHeight":1601,"sourceBytes":1114962,"destBytes":1114962,"author":"salarshani@businessinsider.com (Sarah Al-Arshani)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fd2d1a4e00bce00188bab0a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-35-23-719_72fd31b17006c708.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-32-215_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn31@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-28-361_1c17260aaad81d4f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn39@2020_6/2020/12/11/08-35-25-778_46a316a47cb79541.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn10@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-26-907_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AzpUFCY-3Wc:777hrdVrmgM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn83@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-29-463_eedbfc6a09c4edce.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/AzpUFCY-3Wc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-35-28-383_710db291f3ccd024.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607675712035},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"How to use your iPhone as a fully functional Roku remote, when you can't find the regular remote control","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-use-iphone-as-roku-remote","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd130e448a2590018262864?format=jpeg\" alt=\"roku remote w/person!\" height=\"910\" width=\"1821\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>It&#39;s easy to replace your Roku remote with an iPhone.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Hollis Johnson/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can use your iPhone as a Roku remote should you ever lose your remote control.&#160;</li>\n<li>To use your iPhone as a Roku remote, you'll just need to download the Roku app and link it to your Roku device.</li>\n<li>You'll need to make sure that your iPhone is connected to the same Wi-Fi network as your Roku device in order to link them.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It seems that as TVs get smarter, their remotes just get smaller. The lack of need for things like numbered buttons make it so remotes like a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/roku\">Roku's</a> can be much smaller and more compact - but also, unfortunately, easier to lose.</p><p>Don't worry, though - losing your remote doesn't mean you can't watch TV anymore. If you have an iPhone, it's just as easy to use your phone as the remote - all you need to do is download the app. The buttons, minus any shortcuts you may have for services like Netflix or Hulu, are the same.</p><h2>How to use your iPhone as a Roku remote</h2><p><strong>1. </strong>Go to the App Store and download the <a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/roku-official-remote/id482066631\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Roku remote app</a>. Make sure you choose the right one, as it isn't always the top option: The real app is labeled \"Roku - Official Remote.\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd12c85240ebd00126be03f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to use iPhone as Roku Remote   1\" height=\"1334\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Open the App Store and download the Roku remote app.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melanie Weir/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>2. </strong>Find it and open it, then tap the Devices tab at the bottom right of the screen. Find the name of the Roku device you're using on the page, then tap it.</p><p>Note: If your TV isn't on, and hasn't been on in the past hour or so, you may have to tap twice - once to wake the device and a second time to connect.</p><p>If you're having trouble connecting, make sure your remote is connected to the same Wi-Fi network as your TV. You might also want to try restarting your Roku app, or the iPhone or Roku device itself.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd12cd048a2590018262832?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to use iPhone as Roku Remote   2\" height=\"1334\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Open the app, go to the &#34;Devices&#34; tab, and tap your chosen device to connect.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melanie Weir/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p><strong>3. </strong>Once you're connected, all you need to do is tap where it says \"Remote\" to begin controlling your Roku TV with your phone.</p><p>You can also tap \"Media\" to find videos, photos, and music on your phone that you can cast to your TV.</p><p>In addition, the Channels button is a shortcut to any of the apps installed on your Roku, as well as the channel store.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd12cf848a2590018262839?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to use iPhone as Roku Remote   3\" height=\"1334\" width=\"750\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Tap either &#34;Remote&#34; button to bring up the remote control menu.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melanie Weir/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><div 2020 21:16:17 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fd1309d240ebd00126be079?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"449d8f004fd8e8d84468ec6a37a7f1dc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn26@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-35-20-514_27a03048d79d5f99.webp","destWidth":1674,"destHeight":1255,"sourceBytes":61996,"destBytes":61996,"author":"insider@insider.com (Melanie Weir)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fd130e448a2590018262864?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn31@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-32-078_0b01582f592d8498.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fd12c85240ebd00126be03f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn68@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-35-34-642_112b42e4fbe8e10a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fd12cd048a2590018262832?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn55@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-31-380_578ad18d0da0abc3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fd12cf848a2590018262839?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn6@2020_5/2020/12/11/08-35-34-207_ccb30c57fc772941.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-32-215_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=axPBIFODzWY:CMXcTyaecpU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn59@2020_3/2020/12/11/08-35-23-914_55b10831bdabb2da.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=axPBIFODzWY:CMXcTyaecpU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn71@2020_1/2020/12/11/08-35-27-386_efff8ec5c0ea0460.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn10@2020_2/2020/12/11/08-35-26-907_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=axPBIFODzWY:CMXcTyaecpU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn100@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-34-832_122a7790590b7e3d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/axPBIFODzWY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn80@2020_4/2020/12/11/08-35-28-058_943974f31b2f945f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1607675712075},{"createdTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","updatedTime":"2020-12-11 16:35:12","title":"Pfizer's COVID shot just won endorsement from an expert panel, and FDA could greenlight it within days","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-on-fda-covid-19-vaccine-advisory-committee-pfizer-2020-12","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd0fd1acee0cf00114fa685?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pfizer vaccine\" height=\"3592\" width=\"7186\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Vincent Kalut / Photonews via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A group of independent experts met Thursday to discuss whether the FDA should authorize Pfizer's COVID-19 shot.</li>\n<li>After hours of discussion, the group voted 17-4 in favor of green-lighting the shot. One member abstained.</li>\n<li>The FDA still has the ultimate authority to make the regulatory decision on its own. The agency typically follows expert panels' advice, but it isn't required to do so.</li>\n<li>What follows is a minute-by-minute breakdown of the meeting. Click <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fda-advisory-committee-endorses-pfizers-covid-19-vaccine-2020-12\">here</a> for an overview of the verdict.</li>\n<li><a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-healthcare\">For more stories like this, sign up here for Business Insider's daily healthcare newsletter.</a></li>\n</ul>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\t5:37 PM: Expert panel votes 17-4 in favor of Pfizer's vaccine for emergency OK\n\t\n\t<p>A committee of more than 20 leading scientists and doctors <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fda-advisory-committee-endorses-pfizers-covid-19-vaccine-2020-12\">just voted 17 to 4</a>, advising the US Food and Drug Administration to grant emergency use authorization for Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine in the US. One voting member abstained.</p><p>An FDA decision could come soon after the meeting.&#160;</p><p>Some members had brought up concerns about the wording of the voting question, which asked if the benefits outweigh the risks to OK the shot for people 16 years and older. Some members expressed a desire to increase the minimum age to 18.</p><p>If the FDA authorizes Pfizer's vaccine, that would kick off the largest vaccination campaign in the history of the US. Operation Warp Speed, the federal government's vaccine initiative, plans to start shipping doses to states within 24 hours of authorization.</p>\n\t5:30 PM - Committee members debate if two months of safety follow-up is enough, as voting begins\n\t\n\t<p>Over decades of vaccine trials, the overwhelming majority of issues pop up in the first few weeks, within about 40 days. That gave some members confidence that this vaccine is safe.&#160;</p><p>Dr. Cody Meissner, chief of the pediatrics infectious disease division at Tufts University School of Medicine, said he's \"comfortable\" with the available safety data, particularly given the urgency of the pandemic that is killing thousands of Americans daily.</p><p>Others, though, weren't sure, stressing that this is uncharted territory.&#160;</p><p>Pfizer's vaccine is based on a brand-new technological platform called messenger RNA. One committee member expressed concerns that there isn't any long-term data that spans many months available.&#160;</p><p>In particular, Oveta Fuller, a microbiology and immunology professor at the University of Michigan, raised the unknown about what could happen if vaccinated people are later exposed to COVID-19.&#160;</p><p>\"We've only been looking for two months,\" Fuller said, later adding that \"the uptake in the community is going to be fairly poor unless something better is done.\"</p>\n\t4:51 PM: Pfizer provided details on allergic reactions to its vaccine in the UK. One committee member pressed the drugmaker to address concerns by running an allergy-focused study.\n\t\n\t<p>Pfizer said that people with allergies weren't excluded from the vaccine trial. However, people with previous allergic reactions to vaccines were not allowed in.</p><p>Pfizer senior vice president William Gruber acknowledged he did not know if anyone enrolled in the study had a prior history of any anaphylaxis.</p><p>\"The nature of what was excluded from the trial was really restricted to those individuals who had a severe allergic reaction to a vaccine, any vaccine previously,\" Gruber said. \"During the course of the trial, we have not seen anything that alerted us to a safety signal associated with the vaccine or potential for anaphylaxis.\"&#160;</p><p>Patrick Caubel, the head of safety at Pfizer spoke about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-ingredients-allergic-reactions-2020-12\">two vaccinated people who had adverse reactions to Pfizer's drug in the first days of the UK rollout</a>. He said:</p><ul><li>Both individuals were in their 40s (a 40-year-old, and a 49-year-old), and had medical histories of allergic reactions</li><li>One patient had a history of anaphylaxis, with severe allergies to foods including eggs, cheesecake, and lemon. She reacted a few minutes after getting the shot, and required an IV injection of epinephrine, then fully recovered.</li><li>The second patient had a history of allergies to drugs, though \"we don't know which drugs yet\" Caubel said. She also required an epinephrine injection. Her case was more minor, Caubel said, with some shortness of breath. She also fully recovered.</li></ul><p>Committee member and vaccine expert Dr. Paul Offit said Pfizer should now run a smaller trial focused on people with food allergies, vaccinating them and watching them closely.</p><p>\"This issue is not going to die until we have better data,\" Offit said. \"You're talking about tens of millions of people who are not going to get this vaccine because of the comments that were made both by the UK, and by [Operation Warp Speed chief advisor] Moncef Slaoui here.\"</p><p>&#160;</p>\n\t3:55 PM: The committee will vote on just one question: Do the benefits of Pfizer's vaccine outweigh its risks for use in people 16 and up?\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd28b372dc42e0018f0e48f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FDA question\" height=\"292\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=owveMJBTc2I\" target=\"_blank\">FDA VRBPAC / YouTube</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>All indications are pointing to a \"yes\" verdict, but we'll see what happens when the vote takes place. It's scheduled for around 5:15 p.m. Eastern time.</p>\n\t3:15 PM: How the FDA views the benefits and risks of Pfizer's vaccine\n\t\n\t<p>FDA scientist Dr. Susan Wollersheim discussed how the agency views the benefits and risks of issuing an emergency OK for Pfizer's vaccine.</p><p>These will likely be the key topics for an open-ended discussion the expert panel will start in about an hour, ultimately leading to a vote on whether or not to recommend the two-dose vaccination.</p><p>The key benefit is, unsurprisingly, protection from COVID-19. The trial showed the shot is 95% effective at preventing COVID-19 at least seven days after people finished the two-dose regimen. The FDA noted that it's not clear how long that protection will last.</p><p>The agency reviewers also said that benefit held true across different ages, races, ethnicities, and health conditions like obesity and diabetes.</p><p>The FDA didn't identify any major safety concerns, but noted there were high levels of expected, temporary side effects like pain at the injection site, fatigue, and headache. For most people, these side effects were mild or moderate in intensity and lasted a day or two.</p><p>Wollersheim also said it is possible that there were serious adverse events related to the vaccine, including shoulder injury and enlarged lymph nodes.</p><p>Data was also limited on 16- and 17-year-olds, Wollersheim noted, but the safety profile from young adults could be extrapolated for these older teenagers. The study was also limited by excluding pregnant women and by having limited follow-up time.</p>\n\t12:30 PM: \"Let's roll:\" Pfizer trial participant argues an emergency OK should be granted right now\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd261e130f2740018b0f1f8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Evan Fein FDA Pfizer trial participant\" height=\"400\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Evan Fein said he&#39;s had the vaccine for about five months now, and is enjoying exercising, and helping out his older parents.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=owveMJBTc2I\" target=\"_blank\">FDA VRBPAC / YouTube</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Evan Fein, a participant in Pfizer's vaccine trial, said he believes the vaccine should receive emergency use authorization (EUA) immediately to help save lives.&#160;</p><p>\"An EUA must be granted and must be granted tonight,\" Fein said during an hour-long session for public comment Thursday afternoon. \"Most Americans will take the vaccine voluntarily, as long as we're honest, don't talk down to them, and treat them like autonomous adults.\"</p><p>Fein said he received his first shot in a Pfizer study more than five months ago, on July 1.</p><p>\"I think I got a real vaccine, and not a placebo,\" Fein said, noting he felt \"mild\" effects afterwards, including a fever, chills, and pain where his shot was injected the second time.&#160;</p><p>He said he was impressed with the study's follow-up, with calls from doctors and researchers. \"Nothing felt rushed, and I never felt like a guinea pig,\" he said.&#160;</p><p>He's not worried about long-term side effects, either:</p><p>\"It's been more than five months now since my first shot, and I can happily report that there are none,\" Fein added. \"I've helped out my older parents, I've gone to work in person, and I've exercised in small groups, and I haven't gotten COVID-19.\"&#160;</p><p>Given the emergency posed by the pandemic, Fein said \"the burden of proof is on those who don't want to authorize the vaccine,\" calling it \"immoral and unethical\" to not allow healthcare workers and first responders who want the shot to get it.</p><p>Fein compared the pandemic's devastation to another American tragedy: the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. He noted the daily death toll from the virus now exceeds the number of lives lost on 9/11.</p><p>\"In the words of Todd Beamer, let's roll,\" Fein concluded, referring to the famous last words of a passenger on one of the hijacked flights.</p>\n\t11:10 AM: The CDC wants to text you to see if the vaccine is safe in the real world\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd24a387b7e0500191072b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"V-Safe vaccine monitoring program from CDC for coronavirus vaccines\" height=\"516\" width=\"950\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>How V-SAFE, a new vaccine monitoring program from CDC, will work for coronavirus vaccines.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/acip/meetings/downloads/slides-2020-09/COVID-03-Shimabukuro.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">CDC</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Dr. Nancy Messonnier, a top Centers for Disease Control and Prevention official, told the committee that continuing to monitor the vaccines for safety and effectiveness as they are rolled out to the public is a \"top priority\" of the US government.</p><p>There's a range of monitoring systems to keep tabs on the shots, both new and old.&#160;</p><p>One new system, called V-SAFE, will follow people after they get the shots with text messages and web-based surveys. But to be useful, Messonnier, said, people will need to opt-in to V-SAFE and participate.</p><p>\"We really need people to sign onto this program to give us the best data possible,\" she told the committee.&#160;</p><p>The federal government is also rolling out <a href=\"https://www.brown.edu/academics/public-health/news/2020/11/brown-university-receives-grant-develop-adverse-events-monitoring-system-nursing-home\">another new tracking program</a> tailored for long-term care facilities, built in partnership between the National Institutes of Health, Brown University, and Genesis HealthCare. It will monitor roughly 35,000 long-term care residents at 250 facilities across the US, Messonnier said. Nursing homes are expected to be prioritized to receive the shot.</p><p>Messonnier said that vaccine efficacy may turn out to be different in the real world, when millions of people are getting shots, than it was in clinical trial conditions. Already, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-covid-19-vaccine-ingredients-allergic-reactions-2020-12\">two patients have had allergic reactions to the vaccine</a> in the UK. There were no allergy issues in Pfizer's trials of more than 44,000 individuals in six countries.&#160;</p>\n\t10:26 AM: CDC scientist gives grim update on pandemic's impact in US, highlighting the urgent need for a vaccine\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd23c8730f2740018b0f0b0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"grim chart aron CDC at FDA meeting \" height=\"460\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The CDC&#39;s Aron Hall displayed a staggering chart, showing the trends in the numbers of COVID-19 cases in the US over time.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=owveMJBTc2I\" target=\"_blank\">FDA VRBPAC Meeting / YouTube</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Aron Hall, chief of the respiratory viruses branch at the CDC, gave a grim update on the current state of COVID-19 in the US.</p><p>Hall's update is particularly jarring given the optimistic progress with vaccines. In total, more than 14.8 million people in the US have had confirmed coronavirus infections, resulting in more than 280,000 deaths, he said.</p><p>The pandemic is raging like never before in the US. The April peak was driven by spread in New York City, and a July surge came from the southern US. But Hall noted cases have been rising again since September, with the sharpest increases in the past couple months. More than 3,000 people <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/12/09/world/covid-19-coronavirus#a-grim-new-record-for-the-us-as-daily-deaths-from-the-virus-top-3000\">died from COVID-19 in the US yesterday</a> &#8212; a new record.&#160;</p><p>The committee must weigh the benefits, and consequences, of approving the vaccine in this context. The pandemic's devastation isn't news to anyone, but Hall's presentation shows just how desperate the need for a vaccine is right now.&#160;</p>\n\t9:45 AM: The committee is an impressive mix of more than 20 virologists, doctors, and leading public health experts. There's one lawyer and one competing pharmaceutical maker in attendance too.\n\t\n\t<p>Some of the more prominent <a href=\"https://www.fda.gov/media/144232/download\">committee members</a> from the world of medicine include:&#160;</p><ul><li>Dr. Eric Rubin, an infectious-disease specialist and editor-in-chief of The New England Journal of Medicine.</li><li>Dr. Paul Offit, a top vaccine expert at the University of Pennsylvania who co-invented the rotavirus vaccine.</li><li>Dr. Cody Meissner, chief of the pediatrics infectious disease division at Tufts University School of Medicine.</li><li>Dr. Stanley Perlman, a virology professor from the University of Iowa who has been studying coronaviruses for nearly four decades.&#160;</li></ul><p>Dr. Paula Annunziato, who works in vaccine research at Merck is the non-voting industry representative, and Sheldon Toubman, a lawyer from New Haven, is attending as a consumer representative. He often works <a href=\"https://www.nhregister.com/news/article/Legal-aid-lawyer-sounds-warning-on-Medicaid-cut-12855429.php\">as a legal aid lawyer</a> for low-income families.</p>\n\t9:04 AM: As meeting gets underway, FDA reveals the question of the day.\n\t\n\t<p>The expert panel <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=owveMJBTc2I&#38;feature=youtu.be\">is now underway</a>, virtually, starting with opening remarks and introductions led by the committee's chair, Arnold Monto, a professor of epidemiology and global public health at the University of Michigan.</p><p>These meetings typically take quite a while &#8212; finishing by 5:15 p.m. is more a goal than a hard stopping point. The most interesting discussion usually comes close to the end of the day, when the committee is allowed to have a free-flowing dialogue ahead of the big vote. On today's agenda, that should start around 3:10 p.m.&#160;</p><p>The FDA committee will only vote on one yes-or-no question at the end of the day:&#160;</p><p><em>\"Based on the totality of scientific evidence available, do the benefits of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine outweigh its risks for use in individuals 16 years of age and older?\"</em></p><p>New documents released just now show the FDA wants the panel to also weigh in on a couple of hot topics. First, what should researchers do with trial volunteers who received a placebo shot? There's a difficult tradeoff between the benefits of following those people for long-term data at the cost of withholding an effective vaccine and exposing them to the pandemic.</p><p>Secondly, the agency is asking the group to discuss if they see any gaps in the plans to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the shot going forward.</p>\n\t9:01 AM: FDA boss Stephen Hahn says \"we intend to act quickly\" after today's meeting.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fd24aaa7b7e0500191072b7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"stephen hahn\" height=\"1466\" width=\"1955\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>FDA Commissioner Stephen Hahn\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pete Marovich/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>The head of the FDA <a href=\"https://www.today.com/video/fda-commissioner-stephen-hahn-we-need-to-get-to-herd-immunity-97466437881\">told NBC's Savannah Guthrie</a> he will listen to the advisory committee's discussion today, but ultimately, it's up to him and the FDA's in-house scientists to decide whether to approve or reject the Pfizer vaccine for emergency use in the US.</p><p>And, he hinted that the agency may already be leaning towards a favorable decision for Pfizer's shot, saying \"our initial assessment is that this is a vaccine that does meet our criteria.\"</p><p>\"We have the advisory committee to get outside opinions about this,\" commissioner Hahn said Thursday morning on TODAY.</p><p>\"We think it's very important for transparency. We're the only regulatory agency in the world that has a public vetting of the data. But we'll make that decision. Our scientific experts will make that decision.\"&#160;</p><p>Hahn also suggested that official decision could come as soon as this evening, shortly after the committee's vote:&#160;</p><p>\"We'll have to see what the scientific and medical discussion is today. But our plan is to take their recommendations into account for our decision making and make a decision shortly thereafter. Again, it really depends upon the complexity of the issues discussed, but we intend to act quickly.\"</p>\n\t8:00 AM: 7 unanswered questions we expect answers for today.\n\t\n\t<p>The advisory committee meeting is set to begin one hour from now, at 9 a.m. ET, with <a href=\"https://www.fda.gov/media/144231/download\">a very full agenda</a> slated to last until 5:15 p.m.</p><p>Unlike many FDA advisory committee meetings, the pros and cons of the vaccine aren't likely to stir much debate, given the scale of the coronavirus outbreak across the US right now. It's widely expected that the committee will recommend the vaccine should receive emergency use authorization &#8212; teeing up the FDA to officially OK the vaccine to go into arms across America in the coming days.&#160;</p><p>We've already seen lots of data about this vaccine, both in what <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-to-know-about-first-effective-coronavirus-vaccine-pfizer-2020-11\">Pfizer initially described in November about the shots' efficacy,</a> and in far more detail through independently-vetted <a href=\"https://www.fda.gov/advisory-committees/advisory-committee-calendar/vaccines-and-related-biological-products-advisory-committee-december-10-2020-meeting-announcement\">briefing documents released Tuesday by the FDA</a>. Those documents showed FDA scientists making the case that Pfizer's vaccine had no major safety concerns, and was overwhelmingly protective &#8212; 95% effective at preventing symptomatic COVID-19.</p><p>Even so, the devil is often in the details. Some of the most interesting debates we expect today will be on nuanced topics, with this group of virologists, vaccine experts, and biostatisticians digging deep to get the full picture about what we know &#8212; and don't know &#8212; about this shot.&#160;</p><p>Here are seven of the most burning questions we are most eagerly looking forward to (hopefully) hearing some answers to today:&#160;</p><ol><li><strong>How much protection do people get after their first shot?</strong> Data released Tuesday suggested one Pfizer shot was about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pfizer-ceo-albert-bourla-big-mistake-skip-second-covid-shot-2020-12\">50% effective at preventing COVID-19 in the 21-day period</a> until people got their second (booster) shot. If that partial protection is legit, that would be a valuable benefit to know when immunizing people. Although experts have stressed it will still be essential to get the second dose for the more robust, 95% protection.</li><li><strong>How durable is the protection?</strong> Given that Pfizer's earliest coronavirus vaccine trials only started a few months ago, we probably won't know how long Pfizer's vaccine protection typically lasts, but the committee can unearth any new information they've discovered about waning immunity. Is the trial showing any signs that participants who've had the vaccine for several months now are losing their protection? Or is it still too early to tell?&#160;</li><li><strong>Does the vaccine also prevent transmission to unvaccinated people?</strong> The Pfizer vaccine trial was designed to measure if the shots prevent people from getting symptomatic disease, the kind of coronavirus that might prompt a fever, cough, or more serious issues. The results are an unambiguous success on that front. But that doesn't necessarily mean the vaccine can stop people from being infected. If vaccinated people can still be asymptomatic carriers, unknowingly spreading the virus to others who have not yet been vaccinated, that would have big public-health consequences. Is there any data to suggest one way or the other whether the shot provides so-called 'sterilizing immunity'?&#160;</li><li><strong>What happens to the placebo group now that we know the shot works?</strong> Half of the roughly 40,000 volunteers in Pfizer's trial got a placebo shot (aka no treatment) and they still don't know they're walking around vaccine-free. Keeping the study blinded allows researchers to continue to gather valuable information &#8212; particularly in figuring out the durability of the vaccine's protection. But it poses an ethical conundrum as well. When should the placebo group be offered the real vaccine, particularly if it's known to be very safe and effective? The committee is likely to have thoughts on what should happen next.</li><li><strong>Is there enough data on really old people to classify the shot as fully safe for them?</strong> We're not talking about the 55-plus seniors group, but people in their 80s and 90s. With nursing homes being a top immunization priority, this is a relevant population to make sure will be safe to vaccinate. Data released Tuesday showed 860 people in Pfizer's trial (out of more than 21,000 participants worldwide) were over the age of 75, with the oldest person being 89 years old. Is that a rigorous enough experiment to satisfy the committee and OK this shot to be rolled out to nursing homes across the nation?</li><li><strong>What can we learn from the non-responders?</strong> Some of the most valuable insights may be gleaned from people who got Pfizer's vaccine and still got sick. Fortunately, there weren't a lot of them. Just one volunteer on the active arm registered a severe case of COVID-19 (compared to nine severe cases who were given the placebo) and there were eight cases of COVID-19 overall who got Pfizer's shot (compared to 162 in the placebo group). Can that handful of cases tell us something we don't know about who may or may not respond poorly to this vaccine?&#160;</li><li><strong>What about allergic reactions?</strong> UK health regulators have warned that people with a history of severe allergic reactions shouldn't get Pfizer's shot, after two adverse events were observed in the British rollout. Is there a suitable explanation from Pfizer for why that may be a case, particularly given this vaccine was developed using messenger RNA, a new technology platform? And will this expert panel make a similar recommendation in restricting who should get the shot?</li></ol>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
